this classification encompasses the disposal of various types of waste that are generated from municipal and industrial activities. It includes materials that are no longer usable and require appropriate disposal methods to mitigate environmental impact. The focus is on the correct management and treatment of waste to ensure public health and safety, as well as compliance with regulations. This category covers a wide range of discarded items, including organic, recyclable, and hazardous materials, with the goal of promoting responsible waste management practices. The classification emphasizes the importance of sustainable disposal solutions that reduce landfill use and encourage recycling, while also addressing the specific needs associated with various waste types, ensuring that each is handled according to its unique characteristics and potential risks.

this classification encompasses services and activities related to the assembly of various systems, structures, and components. It includes the processes and practices involved in bringing together individual parts to form a complete, functional unit. The focus is on the methodologies, tools, and equipment utilized in the assembly process across diverse sectors. This category is distinct from others that deal with security, planning, waste management, legal matters, personnel services, and other operational functions. It specifically addresses the technical and logistical aspects of assembly, ensuring efficiency and effectiveness in the integration of components. The classification further categorizes the assembly activities into different areas, including equipment, technology, and specialized environments, highlighting the versatility and importance of assembly in manufacturing and service delivery contexts.

this classification encompasses services related to the management and recycling of materials, focusing on processes that ensure responsible disposal, reprocessing, and waste management. It includes activities aimed at minimizing environmental impact through effective waste handling, treatment, and recycling initiatives. This category is distinct from various service offerings, which include security, engineering, legal, personnel, and financial services. It specifically addresses the systematic approaches to waste reduction, recycling, and the cleanup of residual pollution, emphasizing sustainable practices within the waste cycle economy. The services within this classification are tailored to facilitate efficient waste management and promote environmental stewardship.
includes all services that can be assigned to the domain marketing (see segment 41)

this classification encompasses services focused on providing expert advice, guidance, and support to organizations and individuals across various domains. It includes activities that aid in improving operational efficiency, enhancing strategic decision-making, and fostering organizational development. The services may involve analyzing current practices, recommending improvements, and assisting with the implementation of solutions. This classification is distinct from other service categories, focusing specifically on areas such as management consulting, technology consulting, quality assurance, financial advisory, and personnel management support. It encompasses a wide range of consulting expertise, ensuring that clients can access specialized knowledge to address their unique challenges and goals.

this classification encompasses services related to the management and provision of financial products, risk assessment, and the facilitation of financial transactions. It includes various offerings that support individuals, businesses, and organizations in their financial planning, investment strategies, and risk mitigation. Services in this category are designed to enhance financial security, manage assets, and optimize the allocation of funds. Additionally, it covers services that provide assistance with tax obligations, billing processes, and accounting functions, ensuring compliance and efficiency in financial operations. This classification emphasizes the importance of financial stewardship and the role of insurance in safeguarding against unforeseen events.

this classification encompasses services provided by third-party entities to execute specific tasks or processes on behalf of another organization. These services are characterized by the delegation of specialized activities that require expertise or resources not available internally. The focus is on enhancing operational efficiency through external partnerships, allowing organizations to concentrate on their core competencies while leveraging the skills and capabilities of external providers. This category includes a diverse range of specialized activities aimed at fulfilling operational requirements across various industries. It is distinct from other service offerings such as security, legal, or personnel management services, and it includes various specialized processes tailored to meet the unique needs of different sectors.

this classification encompasses services related to the examination, evaluation, and testing of materials, products, and processes in laboratory and inspection settings. It involves systematic approaches to ensure quality, safety, and compliance with regulatory standards. Services include various forms of analytical testing, inspection of raw materials and finished goods, and specialized studies that support research and development activities. The scope covers both routine inspections and advanced methodologies tailored to specific sectors, including pharmaceuticals and bio-analytics. Additionally, it incorporates activities that assess environmental impact and waste management, ensuring that all processes adhere to established guidelines and best practices. The classification aims to facilitate the identification and organization of services that contribute to the integrity and performance of products and processes within diverse industries.

this classification encompasses services that facilitate the exchange and management of information and communication technologies. It includes a range of offerings aimed at enhancing connectivity, data handling, and communication efficiency. The services are designed to support various operational needs, enabling organizations to leverage technology for improved collaboration and information dissemination. This category includes specialized services that focus on the optimization of digital systems, ensuring seamless interaction between users and devices, and fostering innovation in communication practices. It serves as a vital component for businesses looking to enhance their digital infrastructure and improve overall operational effectiveness through integrated technology solutions.

this classification encompasses a diverse range of educational and instructional activities aimed at enhancing knowledge and skills across various fields. It focuses on structured learning experiences that facilitate personal and professional growth. The offerings within this category include specialized training programs designed to improve competencies in areas such as science, health, technology, craftsmanship, and management. Additionally, it addresses the needs of individuals seeking to advance their qualifications or transition into new roles through targeted learning initiatives. The intention is to empower individuals with the necessary expertise to thrive in their respective domains, fostering a culture of continuous learning and development.

Segment includes a wide range of non-specific services (excluding maintenance or logistics) that provide cross-sector support and functions for companies and consumers. This includes, for example, consulting, administration, training, customer service and cleaning.

a collection of by-products resulting from the combustion of organic materials, often containing a mixture of inorganic and organic compounds. These remnants may vary in composition and can include residues from various combustion processes. The disposal of such materials requires adherence to environmental regulations and guidelines to minimize potential contamination and hazards associated with their presence. Proper management strategies are essential to ensure safe handling and disposal, as well as to promote recycling or recovery of usable components when feasible. This classification encompasses all forms of ashes generated from diverse sources, highlighting the importance of their responsible disposal in waste management practices.

residual material resulting from the combustion of organic or inorganic substances, primarily used in energy production or industrial processes. This material typically consists of fine particles and ash, which may contain various chemical compounds and elements. The disposal of this type of waste is subject to specific environmental regulations and standards to ensure safe handling and minimize ecological impact. Proper management involves assessment of its hazardous characteristics, treatment options, and compliance with disposal protocols to mitigate risks to human health and the environment. This category excludes other forms of waste such as municipal, industrial, and recyclable materials, focusing specifically on the unique characteristics and disposal requirements of cinder.

residual pollution refers to the leftover materials and substances that remain after the processing or consumption of products and services, which do not fit into specific categories of waste. This classification encompasses various types of waste that may contain contaminants or undesirable components, requiring specialized disposal methods to mitigate environmental impact. It includes items that are not easily categorized as standard waste types, often necessitating distinct treatment or disposal strategies to ensure compliance with environmental regulations and promote safe handling. The focus is on managing these residuals effectively to minimize harm to ecosystems and human health, addressing the complexity of disposal requirements associated with diverse waste streams.

this classification refers to the disposal of particulate matter that can be generated from various processes, including construction, industrial operations, or natural occurrences. It encompasses fine particles that are typically not hazardous but require proper management to avoid environmental contamination. Disposal methods may include landfilling, incineration, or other environmentally responsible techniques. The focus is on ensuring that the waste is handled in accordance with regulations to mitigate potential impacts on public health and the environment. This category distinctly separates itself from other types of waste disposal by specifically addressing the management of dust, which may arise from various sources but is not classified under organic, industrial, or other specific waste types.

this category encompasses processes and methods related to the disposal of materials extracted from oil and gas operations. It involves the handling, treatment, and disposal of waste generated during extraction activities, ensuring compliance with environmental regulations and safety standards. The focus is on managing hazardous and non-hazardous waste resulting from oil and gas extraction, including but not limited to drilling muds, produced water, and other by-products. Proper disposal practices are essential to mitigate environmental impact, prevent contamination, and promote sustainable waste management within the energy sector. This classification distinguishes itself from various types of waste disposal associated with municipal or industrial origins, as well as from specific disposal needs related to recyclable materials, organic refuse, and specialized waste streams.

this classification encompasses substances that are primarily utilized as emulsions, coolants, or lubricants, which are intended for disposal after use. These materials may possess properties that make them hazardous or environmentally sensitive, necessitating specific disposal methods to mitigate potential risks to health and the environment. This category is distinct from general waste types and includes products that can originate from various industrial, automotive, or manufacturing processes. Proper management and disposal of these materials are crucial to ensure compliance with environmental regulations and to promote sustainable waste management practices. The classification seeks to facilitate the identification, handling, and disposal of such substances in a responsible manner, ensuring that they are treated in accordance with relevant safety guidelines and legislation.

a device designed to separate oil from various fluids or mixtures, facilitating the disposal of oil-contaminated waste in an environmentally responsible manner. This equipment is essential in industries where oil and water are combined, ensuring that oil is effectively extracted and treated before disposal. The oil separator plays a critical role in waste management processes, particularly in settings where compliance with environmental regulations is necessary. By efficiently removing oil from waste streams, it helps minimize pollution and reduces the potential impact of oil waste on ecosystems. This classification specifically pertains to systems that handle oily substances, distinguishing them from other waste disposal methods associated with different types of materials and contaminants.

sewage sludge refers to the semi-solid residue generated during the treatment of wastewater, typically from municipal or industrial sources. It contains a mixture of organic and inorganic materials, including nutrients, pathogens, and contaminants, which arise from the breakdown of waste materials. The disposal of sewage sludge involves various methods, such as incineration, landfilling, or processing for beneficial reuse, which may include conversion into fertilizers or energy. This category emphasizes the specific characteristics and disposal requirements of sewage sludge, distinguishing it from other types of waste materials. Proper management and disposal are essential to minimize environmental impact and safeguard public health, ensuring compliance with regulations and standards governing waste treatment and disposal practices.

preferred_name.label: Sludge from industrial waste water purification (disposal)

definition.text: a type of waste material generated from the purification processes of industrial wastewater, characterized by its composition of various pollutants and contaminants that require specialized handling and disposal methods. This category includes materials that have undergone treatment to remove harmful substances but still pose environmental or health risks if not managed properly. The disposal of this waste is governed by strict regulations to mitigate potential negative impacts on the environment, ensuring that it is processed in a manner that complies with safety and sustainability standards. This classification distinguishes it from other waste types that may originate from municipal sources or different industrial processes, highlighting the specific challenges and requirements associated with its disposal.

a substance specifically designed for dissolving other materials, often utilized in industrial or laboratory settings. This category encompasses various chemical compounds that are employed to facilitate processes such as cleaning, thinning, or extracting components from mixtures. The focus is on the disposal aspect, indicating that these solvents have reached the end of their usable life and require proper management to prevent environmental contamination. This classification is distinct from other waste types, emphasizing the unique handling and regulatory considerations necessary for safe disposal to mitigate risks associated with hazardous materials. Proper disposal methods are crucial to ensure compliance with environmental regulations and to protect public health.

abrasive sludge refers to a specific type of waste material generated during processes that involve abrasive substances. This sludge typically contains fine particles and contaminants that may arise from industrial activities, machining, or surface treatment operations. As a waste stream, it requires careful handling and disposal due to potential environmental hazards and regulatory compliance. The disposal of abrasive sludge must adhere to established guidelines to mitigate risks associated with pollution and health. This category is distinct from other waste types, emphasizing the unique characteristics and disposal requirements of materials that may contain hazardous components or require specialized treatment methods.

this classification encompasses a variety of waste materials that are categorized as unwanted byproducts originating from metal-related processes. These materials may include residues that emerge from manufacturing and other industrial activities involving metals. The disposal of these materials typically requires specialized handling due to potential contamination and environmental concerns. Unlike other waste categories, this classification focuses specifically on metal sludge that does not fit into established categories of municipal or industrial waste. It reflects the need for distinct waste management strategies aimed at mitigating environmental impact while ensuring compliance with regulations governing hazardous and non-hazardous waste disposal. The classification serves as a framework for identifying and managing these specific waste streams effectively.

a mixture of various hydrocarbons and other organic materials that accumulate in the form of a viscous, semi-solid mass, typically as a byproduct of oil extraction, refining processes, or industrial operations. This material often contains contaminants and requires specialized treatment or disposal methods to mitigate environmental impact. Proper management of this substance is essential to prevent soil and water contamination, ensuring compliance with environmental regulations and promoting sustainable waste management practices. The disposal process may involve techniques such as incineration, landfilling in designated areas, or treatment to recover usable components, depending on local regulations and technological capabilities.

this classification refers to waste materials generated during workshop operations that are contaminated with oils and similar substances. Such waste typically includes residues, rags, and other items that have been in contact with oily substances and require specialized handling and disposal methods to prevent environmental contamination. The management of this type of waste is crucial to ensure compliance with environmental regulations and to mitigate risks associated with toxic substances. Proper disposal methods are necessary to protect public health and the environment, and they may involve recycling, incineration, or safe landfilling, depending on the characteristics of the waste and local regulations.

this category encompasses waste materials primarily consisting of enamel and paint residues that require specialized disposal methods to prevent environmental contamination. These materials often contain hazardous components that necessitate careful handling, treatment, and disposal processes. The classification aims to differentiate these specific waste types from broader waste categories, ensuring that the unique characteristics and regulatory requirements associated with enamel and paint waste are adequately addressed. Proper disposal practices are essential to mitigate potential risks to public health and the environment, emphasizing the need for adherence to applicable regulations and standards in waste management.

this classification refers to materials that are used for bonding, sealing, or coating purposes and are no longer suitable for their intended use, requiring disposal. These substances may be derived from synthetic or natural origins and can include various formulations like adhesives, cements, and resins. The disposal process for these materials must adhere to specific regulations to manage environmental impact effectively. Proper handling and treatment are essential to prevent contamination and ensure compliance with waste management standards. This category is distinct from other waste types, focusing specifically on materials that pose unique challenges in terms of their chemical composition and potential hazards during disposal.

this classification pertains to waste materials resulting from the distillation process that are deemed unsuitable for further use or processing, necessitating their disposal. Such residues may contain a variety of compounds, including but not limited to hydrocarbons, solvents, and other chemical byproducts, which have undergone separation during distillation. Proper disposal methods are essential to mitigate environmental impact and comply with regulatory requirements. The classification is distinct from other types of waste disposal, focusing specifically on the remnants from distillation procedures, which may vary in composition and toxicity. This category addresses the safe and responsible management of distillation residues, ensuring that they are handled in a manner that protects public health and the environment.

a type of waste material generated from galvanic processes, which involves the use of electrochemical reactions for surface treatment of metals. This waste typically consists of residues that may include heavy metals, chemicals, and other contaminants derived from the galvanization process. Proper disposal of this waste is crucial due to potential environmental hazards and regulatory compliance. The management of this type of waste requires specialized handling and treatment methods to mitigate risks associated with heavy metal contamination and to ensure safe disposal in accordance with environmental regulations. This classification is distinct from other waste types, focusing specifically on residues produced in galvanic operations.

this classification pertains to waste materials that consist of various oxides and hydroxides, which are typically generated from different industrial processes, chemical reactions, or other activities. These substances may not fit neatly into more commonly recognized waste categories and can include a range of inorganic compounds. The disposal of these materials is critical to ensure environmental safety and compliance with regulations. Proper management and disposal methods aim to minimize potential harm to human health and the ecosystem. This category encompasses a diverse array of waste types that require careful consideration during disposal to mitigate risks associated with chemical contamination and environmental impact.

a classification that encompasses substances primarily consisting of various types of salts intended for disposal purposes. This category is specifically designed to address the management and processing of salt-based materials that are no longer usable or required, ensuring safe and compliant disposal methods. It includes a range of salts derived from industrial processes, agricultural activities, or other sources, which may pose environmental or health risks if not handled properly. The classification highlights the distinct nature of these substances compared to other types of waste, emphasizing their unique characteristics and the regulatory considerations involved in their disposal.

a highly corrosive liquid substance comprising a concentrated aqueous solution that can cause significant damage to organic material and is classified for proper disposal due to its hazardous nature. This substance requires specialized handling and disposal procedures to mitigate environmental and health risks associated with its release or improper disposal. It is distinct from various forms of waste classified under typical disposal categories, as it poses unique challenges and regulatory requirements in waste management practices. Its disposal is critical to ensuring safety and compliance with environmental protection standards.

this classification encompasses substances that are categorized as hazardous or non-hazardous chemical materials requiring specific disposal methods due to their potential environmental or health impacts. These materials may arise from various industrial processes, laboratories, or households and necessitate specialized handling to ensure compliance with regulatory standards. The disposal of these chemicals is crucial for reducing pollution, preventing soil and water contamination, and safeguarding public health. It includes a range of chemical substances that cannot be disposed of through regular waste streams and require treatment, recycling, or safe disposal methods to mitigate their effects on the ecosystem.

this classification encompasses the disposal of waste materials generated from sanitation processes. It includes various types of waste that require specific handling due to their nature and potential impact on health and the environment. The focus is on materials that arise from sanitation facilities, including but not limited to, refuse from public health systems, biosolids, and similar by-products. The classification distinguishes activities and types of waste associated with the disposal of these materials, ensuring they are managed in compliance with relevant regulations and best practices. This category serves as a framework for identifying and organizing the disposal methods and requirements unique to sanitation-related waste, emphasizing safe and responsible management practices.

this classification refers to waste generated from medical and healthcare facilities, including hospitals, clinics, and laboratories. It encompasses materials that may pose health risks due to their biological, chemical, or radioactive nature. Proper disposal is essential to prevent contamination and protect public health and the environment. This category is distinct from other waste types, as it requires specialized handling, treatment, and disposal methods to mitigate potential hazards. The aim is to ensure safe management of waste that may include sharps, infectious materials, and other hazardous substances resulting from medical procedures, patient care, or research activities.

this classification encompasses non-hazardous materials collected from road surfaces, including debris, dirt, leaves, and other organic and inorganic residues resulting from road maintenance activities. It pertains specifically to the disposal of such materials, which may contain a mix of particulate matter and contaminants accumulated from traffic and environmental exposure. The focus is on ensuring proper treatment and disposal methods that adhere to environmental regulations and promote sustainable waste management practices. This category distinguishes itself from other waste types by its origins and characteristics, emphasizing the unique handling requirements associated with road maintenance by-products.

this classification refers to the disposal of vehicles that are no longer operational or deemed unsuitable for continued use. It encompasses the processes and methods employed to manage such vehicles in an environmentally responsible manner, ensuring that hazardous materials are removed, and recyclable components are separated. This category emphasizes the importance of adhering to regulations and best practices during the disposal process, thereby minimizing environmental impact and promoting resource recovery. The classification is distinct from various other waste disposal categories, focusing specifically on the challenges and requirements associated with the disposal of old vehicles, including safety measures, recycling protocols, and compliance with relevant environmental legislation.

a filtering device specifically designed for the separation and removal of undesirable substances from fluids or gases, typically employed in waste management processes. This type of apparatus is utilized to enhance the quality of effluents or emissions by capturing particulates, contaminants, or impurities before final disposal. It plays a crucial role in ensuring compliance with environmental regulations and standards, contributing to the safe and responsible treatment of waste materials. Through various filtration technologies, such devices can effectively target specific pollutants, thereby improving overall waste processing efficiency and minimizing environmental impact.

a substance or mixture utilized for its capacity to absorb or bond materials, primarily intended for disposal purposes. This category encompasses agents that may be employed in various applications, including but not limited to, the containment and solidification of waste materials. These agents are specifically designed to enhance the disposal process by facilitating safe and efficient management of waste, thereby minimizing environmental impact. The focus is on substances that play a critical role in the treatment or preparation of waste prior to its final disposal, ensuring compliance with regulatory standards and contributing to overall waste management strategies.

a category dedicated to materials utilized for insulation that are no longer suitable for use and require proper disposal. These materials may include a range of substances designed to prevent the transfer of heat, sound, or electricity. Disposal of these insulating materials must adhere to environmental regulations to mitigate potential hazards associated with their composition, which may include harmful substances. The classification emphasizes the importance of responsible disposal practices to protect public health and the environment, distinguishing it from other waste materials that do not possess insulating properties. Proper handling and disposal methods are essential to ensure safe and compliant waste management.
Sub-group (4th level) for objects that cannot be classified into other specified sub-groups in the existing structure, but that are classified to their parent-class on the 3rd level

this classification encompasses the processes and methods associated with the collection, treatment, and disposal of wastewater and related by-products that originate from domestic, commercial, or industrial sources. It includes the management of liquid waste that may contain pollutants, organic matter, and other contaminants. The focus is on ensuring safe and environmentally responsible disposal practices to mitigate health risks and environmental impacts. This category addresses the specific challenges and technologies related to the treatment of sewage, emphasizing the importance of compliance with regulatory standards and sustainability in waste management operations. It is distinct from categories related to other types of waste, which may require different handling and disposal techniques.

this category encompasses a range of specialized services focused on the design, strategizing, and engineering of various projects. It includes activities that facilitate the systematic development of products or systems, ensuring that all engineering principles and planning processes are effectively applied. Services within this classification may cover the creation and assessment of prototypes, architectural blueprints, and process control methodologies. Additionally, it incorporates activities related to automation technology, electrical engineering designs, and the use of computer-aided design and engineering tools. Furthermore, the category addresses the planning and monitoring of renovation projects, as well as surveying and routing tasks essential for project execution. Overall, this classification is dedicated to enhancing the efficiency and innovation of development and engineering services across diverse industries.
Asset (empty)
hierarchical dictionary of products, systems and services according to a logical structure and levels of detail corresponding to the specific properties of these products
representation of a type or family of product (device, equipment, software or service) which can be described by a generic set of properties
